Graphical abstract Nb-modified MgAlmixed oxide catalysts were prepared by ion exchange using an MgAl hydrotalcite and peroxoniobate complex as precursors. After calcination, the Nb-MgAl revealed to be a composite material (MgAl mixed oxide with segregated Nb2O5 nanoparticles), with an increased specific surface area (229 m2 g−1) compared to bare MgAl (88 m2 g−1). XRD confirmed that part of the Nb atoms was inserted in the MgAl lattice thus causing the oxide doping. Furthermore, the Nb precursor favored the incorporation of a high amount of Nb in the catalyst (18 wt.%). Reactions performed in a continuous flow fixed-bed reactor (PBR) on a pilot scale showed that the MgAl and Nb-MgAl are quite active and stable catalysts for the conversion of the waste glycerol (> 90 %), as generated in the biodiesel industry. The valuable chemicals obtained (i.e., diglycerol, formic acid, and dioxane) demonstrates the potential industrial use of the catalysts presented in this work. Keywords Crude glycerol Hydrotalcite Formic acid Diglycerol Mixed oxide Peroxoniobate complex 1 Introduction Glycerol is a valuable biomass derivative from the biodiesel industry. In recent decades, the steady increase in biodiesel production has generated a massive amount of glycerol as a co-product (about 10 wt.% of the blend formed) [1,2]. The production of crude glycerol was 30.8 million m3 in 2016 and it is estimated to reach about 41.0 million m3 in 2022, that is, an excessive volume not completely absorbed by the world market [3]. The main problem is that the waste glycerol, known as glycerin or crude glycerol, also contains salts (e.g. NaCl), methanol, fatty acid methyl esters, and water remaining from the transesterification reaction [4]. Moreover, the purification of the waste glycerol for industrial usage is a costly process and usually unfeasible for several applications [4]. In recent years several catalytic conversion processes of glycerol into value-added chemicals have been proposed. Nevertheless, most of the studies employ the high purity grade commercial glycerol in the catalytic tests, which considerably affects the catalyst performance and reaction products [5,6]. Thus, a proper evaluation of the catalyst can be carried out only by using the crude glycerol as reagent (as generated in the biodiesel industry). For example, Badia-Fabregat et al. [7] reported the use of crude glycerol for hydrogen production. Lopez et al. [8] used transition metals modified hydrotalcite (Fe, Ni, Cu, and Zn) for hydrogenolysis of crude glycerol. Recently, our group prepared metal-free bifunctional silica for the oxidation of the waste glycerol to formic acid [9]. Formic acid is an important commodity chemical in high demand in the pharmaceutical, agricultural, leather, food, and textile industries [10], besides having applications as fuel for fuel cells and as a hydrogen carrier [11,12]. Currently, the synthesis of formic acid is performed from fossil feedstocks, mainly through the hydrolysis of methyl formate [10,11]. Thus, new synthetic routes from renewable sources, such as the crude glycerol, have heightened interest and wide environmental appeal. It should be mentioned that the formic acid price is about 0.68−0.79 US$/Kg (Europe, 2013) [12], while the residual glycerol has a low commercial value, about 0.24 US$/Kg [2]. Moreover, glycerol dehydration is able to produce diglycerol that has high applicability in cosmetics, food, pharmaceutical, and polymer industries [13]. Afterward, the diglycerol molecules can condense forming cyclic ethers that have applications as fuel additives [14]. It must be highlighted that the glycerol conversion to formic acid and diglycerol require the use of bifunctional catalysts, containing both oxidizing and acid/basic sites. Particularly, hydrotalcite (HT) catalysts have been deeply investigated for different reactions such as the glycerol conversion to polyglycerols [15,16]. These lamellar double hydroxides, i.e., HT have high basicity and specific surface area (≈ 100−300 m2 g−1) after heat treatment [17]. Furthermore, the modification of the HT catalysts by niobium addition can modulate the acid/basic character of the catalyst, besides generating oxidizing sites in the presence of hydrogen peroxide [18]. Therefore, in this work we describe the synthesis of unprecedented catalysts based on Nb-modified MgAl hydrotalcite applied to the conversion of waste glycerol into valuable chemicals such as formic acid and diglycerol in a continuous flow reaction system on a pilot scale. 2 Material and methods 2.1 Synthesis of the MgAl hydrotalcite and MgAl mixed oxide The MgAl hydrotalcite (HT) with the Mg/Al molar ratio of 4/1 was synthesized by the co-precipitation method using the aqueous solutions of Mg(NO3)2⋅6H2O (VETEC) and Al(NO3)3⋅9H2O (SIGMA ALDRICH), as described in [19,20]. The metal nitrate solutions with a total metal concentration of 1.0 mol L−1 was slowly added to another solution containing 2.4 mol L−1 (NH4)2CO3, under vigorous magnetic stirring. The suspension pH was maintained constant at 10 ± 0.5 (controlled by the addition of NH4OH, 30 % v/v). Afterward, the precipitate was maintained at 65 °C for 18 h and then washed several times with warm distilled water. The obtained solid hydrotalcite, denoted as HT, was dried in an oven at 100 °C for 24 h. Finally, part of the HT was calcined at 600 °C for 2 h, using a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 for the generation of the MgAl mixed oxide. 2.2 Synthesis of Nb-modified hydrotalcite catalysts Firstly, the Nb precursor (peroxoniobate species) was synthesized. For that, 46.2 mmol of the NH4[NbO(C2O4)2(H2O)](H2O)n salt (provided by CBMM) was dissolved in 100 mL of distilled water at 90 °C. Then, an NH4OH solution (5 mol L−1) was slowly added to the salt solution for precipitation of the Nb oxyhydroxide. The suspension was aged under magnetic stirring for 12 h and the obtained solid was filtered, water-washed and oven-dried at 60 °C for 12 h. Afterward, 8 mL of H2O2 (30 %, v/v) and 100 mL of mili-q water were added to 300 mg of Nb oxyhydroxide. After 12 h, the solid was centrifuged off and the liquid supernatant contained the leached species of peroxoniobate complex [21]. After the preparation of the Nb precursor (peroxoniobate complex), as described above, the synthesized hydrotalcite was submitted to an ion exchange process for Nb addition to the catalysts. For that, 1.5 g of hydrotalcite was added to 200 mL of the aqueous solution containing the peroxoniobate species. After 24 h at room temperature, the suspension was filtered and the solid was oven-dried at 100 °C for 12 h. The obtained catalyst was named Nb-HT. Part of the Nb-HT was calcined under the same conditions described for the pure hydrotalcite (600 °C/2 h) to produce the Nb-MgAl catalyst. 2.3 Catalysts characterization The catalysts were characterized by powder X-ray diffractometry (XRD) in a SHIMADZU (XRD-700 X-RAY DIFFRACTOMETER) with CuK α radiation (λ =1.5406 Å), using 30 mA and 30 kV for X-ray generation. The phases were identified using the Powder Diffraction File (PDF) database (JCPDS, International Centre for Diffraction Data). The cell parameters a and c were estimated using the equations a = 2d(110) and c = 3/2d(003) + 2/3d(006) for the hydrotalcite-like materials [22], and a = 2d(200) for the MgAl mixed oxides [23]. The crystallite sizes were calculated from the Williamson-Hall equation [24]. The textural properties of the catalysts were studied by Nitrogen physisorption at 77 K, using a Quantachrome 2.0 equipment, Autosorb iQ2 model. The samples were previously outgassed at 120 °C for 6 h and the specific surface area was obtained using the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) equation. The pore size distribution was analyzed by the desorption branch of the isotherm following the Barret-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method, at a relative pressure over 0.35. The chemical compositions of the sample’s surface were investigated using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The survey spectra were obtained by a monochromatic Al Kα radiation (1486.6 eV), and an electron energy analyzer (Specs, Phoibos-150) that enables high energy resolution and excellent signal-to-noise ratio. The survey spectra were acquired via step energy of 1eV and pass energy of 100 eV. The high-resolution spectra were acquired using a step of 0.1 eV and pass energy of 20 eV. A flood current of 0.1 μA was used to compensate for charging effects. The signal of adventitious carbon (C 1s at 284.6 eV) was employed as a reference in the calibration of the binding energies (BE) of the elements detected. CasaXPS software was used to process data analysis. The acidic properties of the materials were determined by Temperature Programmed Desorption using NH3 as a probe molecule (TPD of NH3), and the base properties by TPD of CO2. The profiles were obtained through a Quantachrome Chembet-300, TCD detector, current of 150 mA, attenuation of 32. About 0.1 g of the sample was treated at 120 °C (non-calcined solid) or 600 °C (calcined materials) for 10 min under continuous N2 flow (80 mL min−1). The adsorption of NH3 or CO2 was then performed at 50 °C for 20 min and 40 mL min−1. After the physisorbed gases were purged from the sample (under N2 flow for 30 min), the TPD profiles were obtained at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1, from 50 up to 650 °C. TEM-EDX analyses were performed using a Tecnai G2−20-FEI SuperTwin microscope, operating at 200 kV. The powder samples were prepared by their dispersion in ethanol. The X-ray fluorescence (XRF) analyses were performed in a SHIMADZU spectrometer (XRF-7000 X-RAY), operating with a rhodium X-ray target. The analysis set was: 7 μA and 50 kV, for 100 s and 10 mm collimator. Seven reference samples were prepared from the standard reference materials by using the pressed method with sodium-tetra-borate. They were measured and the relationship with the fluorescent X-ray intensity plotted as a calibration curve (R2 = 0.9995), which was used for the quantitation of unknown samples prepared similarly. 2.4 Catalytic tests The catalytic activity of the Nb-modified HT materials was evaluated in the conversion reactions of the waste glycerin, as generated from the biodiesel industry (provided by PetrobrasBiofuels, containing 80 wt.% glycerol, 11 wt.% H2O, 6 wt.% NaCl and 3 wt.% Matter Organic Non-Glycerol - MONG). The reactions were carried out in a continuous flow system using a stainless steel packed bed reactor (PBR) with dimensions of 60 × 1.5 cm (height x diameter). The reactor was filled with 46 mesh silicon carbide and the central part of the reactor was filled with a solid mixture containing 100 mesh silicon carbide and 1 cm3 catalyst. The reaction mixture consisted of a 1/1 (v/v) solution of the residual glycerin and hydrogen peroxide (50 %, v/v), using a continuous feeding flow of 1.0 mL min−1. Aliquots of the liquid products formed in the reactions were collected at regular intervals of 1 h at the end of the condenser connected to the PBR reactor. The volume, mass, and composition of the liquid products were monitored during 8 h of reaction. The reaction products were analyzed by GC–MS, in an Agilent Technologies Model 7890B GC System, coupled to a mass detector model 5977B MSD, using an INOWAX-column. A schematic illustration of the reaction system in a continuous flow using the packed bed reactor is presented in Fig. 1 . 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the catalysts The XRD of the MgAl hydrotalcite (HT) showed characteristic diffractions of hydrotalcite-like compounds (Fig. 2 -a). Moreover, the XRD patterns of Nb-HT suggest that the ion exchange process using the peroxoniobate species preserved the HT structure. However, after the thermal treatment at 600 °C, the HT lamellar structure was destroyed, as expected for this type of material, and allowed the formation of a MgAl mixed oxide of low crystallization degree [PDF 45−0946]. In the case of the Nb-MgAl, besides the MgAl mixed oxide, reflections, related to niobium oxide V (Nb2O5), were detected [PDF 28–317]. Thus, the results revealed that the Nb-MgAl is actually a composite material containing a MgAl mixed oxide and Nb2O5clusters. The electron energy-loss spectroscopy (EELS) in a transmission electron microscope was used as an additional technique for characterization of the niobium phases in the Nb-MgAl catalyst (Fig. 2-c). Indeed, the electronic transitions are typical of Nb2O5 [25,26]. The spectrum showed edges near 230 eV attributed to the electrons transition from 3d orbital of Nb to higher unoccupied 4f and 5p energy levels. The spectrum also showed edges near 350 eV, which is possibly related to the electronic transition from 3p to unoccupied 4d and 5 s levels of Nb. The electronic transitions of O were observed in the range of 540−575 eV (Fig. 2-c). The lattice parameters for HT and mixed oxides were determined from XRD data and are presented in Table 1 . The a parameter corresponds to the cation-cation distance in the brucite-like sheets whereas the c parameter corresponds to the distance of the interlayer space of brucite-like materials [27]. The a and c values for the HT precursor are in good agreement with the literature [28,29]. A slight difference in the c values is usual for hydrotalcite compounds because of its variable hydration degree. From Table 1, it is possible to note that the a values for HT and Nb-HT are rather similar whereas the c value is considerably reduced for Nb-HT. This result indicates that the ion exchange process with the Nb species caused the contraction of the HT structure, reducing the distance of the interlayer space [29]. It should be recalled that the synthesized HT presents CO3 2− as charge compensation anions in their interlayer space. It is possible that the ion exchange process using the oligomeric peroxoniobate complex, of high-density negative charge [30], caused the withdrawal of part of the CO3 2- anions from the interlayer space thus reducing the c parameter value. However, it is unlikely that the bulky peroxoniobate species have entered in the HT interlayer space because of the reduction in the c value for Nb-HT [31]. In order to verify this hypothesis, the nanostructure of the HT and Nb-HT was also investigated by SAXS (Fig. S1). The structural information was obtained by the Power Law of Scattering, calculated from Guinier and Porod analyses. At high scattering angles, the Porod law reflects the surface of the particles whereas at low angles the Guinier law reflects the particle shapes [32]. The slopes of the curves in the Porod region were α = -4.40 and α = -3.11 for HT and Nb-HT, respectively. This indicates that the Nb addition changed the HT surface from smooth to rough. Thus, the result suggests that the Nb oligomers are deposited over the HT surface rather than in the interlayer space. Fig. 3 illustrates the proposed structures for the catalysts. The further analysis of the XRD revealed that the Nb addition to MgAl mixed oxide caused diffraction shifts towards higher 2θ values (Fig. 2-b). In fact, a lower value of the a parameter was determined for Nb-MgAl when compared to the bare MgAl (Table 1). This is a consequence of the lattice contraction of MgAl mixed oxide in the presence of Nb. The Nb5+ cations (64 pm) can replace the Mg2+ cations (72 pm) due to their similar ionic radii, leading to a Nb-doped MgAl cubic structure, as illustrated in Fig. 3-c [33]. The average crystallite size (D) of the samples was estimated by the Williamson-Hall equation (W-H). The H–W method encompasses both size-induced and lattice strain-induced broadening of the XRD peaks [24]. The Nb addition to the HT reduced the crystallite size (D), corroborating the interlamellar distance (c) data (Table 1). After calcination, the MgAl and Nb-MgAl oxides presented similar D values. The Nb amount in the catalysts was determined by XRF (Table 1). It is interesting to note that the synthesis procedure by ion-exchange using the peroxoniobate species was highly efficient to incorporate a large amount of Nb in the catalysts. After calcination, the Nb-HT was converted in the Nb-MgAl mixed oxide that presents a slightly higher Nb loading, as expected, due to the thermal transformations of HT that cause weight losses [35]. XPS analyses were conducted to characterize the chemical state of the surface of the catalysts (Fig. 4 ). The XPS survey spectra of the Nb-HT and Nb-MgAl samples showed the presence of Nb, Mg, Al, and O peaks (Fig. 4-a). The XPS data are summarized in Table 2 . The surface compositions were obtained integrating the respective main peak areas of each element corrected by their correspondent relative sensitivity factors. Interestingly, after calcination, the Nb-MgAl presents a slightly lower atomic concentration of Nb at the catalyst surface, which corroborates the Nb doping effect in the MgAl matrix (Table 2). From Table 2, it is possible to calculate the Mg/Al atomic ratio at the catalyst surfaces. The Nb-HT presents an Mg/Al ratio of 3.1/1.0 that reduced to 2.1/1.0 for Nb-MgAl. This result also suggests that the Nb5+ cations replaced the Mg2+ cations in the MgAl framework, as illustrated in Fig. 3-c. Fig. 4-b displays the location of the Nb 3d levels. No significant changes in B.E. were observed for the catalysts. The two bands of the Nb 3d doublet were deconvoluted and are centered at 207.3 eV (3d5/2) and 210.1–210.2 eV (3d3/2) (Fig. 4-b). These values are typical of Nb(V) in an oxidic environment [36,37]. The TEM analyses were carried out to investigate the morphology and atomic structure of the catalysts (Fig. 5 ). The TEM image of the HT precursor exhibits a well-defined layered structure (Fig. 5-a), typical of two-dimensional (2D) materials. The thickness map obtained by electron energy-loss spectroscopy (EELS) was used to estimate the lamellae size of the HT precursor of about 103 nm (Fig. 5-b), in agreement with the previous results in the literature [38]. The Nb-HT maintained the typical layered structure of the HT precursor after incorporation of Nb species (Fig. 5-c), as already verified using XRD. On the other hand, Fig. 5-d shows that most of the HT layers were thermally decomposed during calcination to produce the MgAl mixed oxide. In the case of the Nb-MgAl (Fig. 5-e), very distinctive regions of grain morphology suggest the composite formation, i.e., an MgAl mixed oxide besides Nb2O5 segregated particles (detected by XRD). The Selected area electron diffraction (SAED) of the Nb-MgAl attests to the polycrystalline nature of the sample (Fig. 5-f). The textural properties of the catalysts were investigated by N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms (Fig. 6 -a and c). All isotherm scan be classified as type IV(a), characteristic of mesoporous materials [39]. The pore size distribution confirmed the presence of mesopores of ≈ 4 nm in all samples, and larger mesopores in a wide range of sizes (Fig. 6-b and d) [39–41]. The HT precursor presented SBET = 65 m2 g−1 and, after Nb addition, the Nb-HT showed a slightly higher SBET (88 m2 g−1). Interestingly, the Nb addition increased the specific surface area of the catalysts, especially in the case of Nb-MgAl (SBET = 229 m2 g−1). This is probably explained by the formation of a composite material containing porous solids like the MgAl mixed oxide, besides niobium oxide V, that possibly contributed to the increase in the SBET [42]. The acid/base properties of the catalysts are important attributes governing the activity for glycerol conversion. The studies were carried out by TPD of NH3(g) and CO2(g) and show that both oxides (MgAl and Nb-MgAl) present acid and base sites on the surface (Fig. 7 ). Concerning the acid sites, the deconvolution of the curves in the TPD-NH3 (Fig. 7-a) showed that the MgAl presents acid sites of medium strength (≈ 200−300 °C) and both catalysts present sites of medium strength (≈ 300−450 °C), possibly attributed to the Al3+ ions present in the MgAl matrix [43]. However, it is clear that the Nb addition created stronger acid sites in the Nb-MgAl, that desorbs NH3 at higher temperatures (centered at 500 °C and > 600 °C), which are likely related to Lewis acid sites present on Nb2O5 surface (Fig. 7-a) [42]. Indeed, the total density of acid sites increased from 20.4 mV m−2 in the MgAl to 25.1 mV m−2 in the Nb-MgAl catalyst. The TPD−CO2 (Fig. 7-b) showed that the MgAl and Nb-MgAl catalysts present base sites of weak and medium strength (≈150−400 °C). For the MgAl mixed oxide derived from hydrotalcite, the general assumption is that the weak base sites are attributed to the hydroxyl groups on the solid surface whereas the medium strength base sites are related to the metal―oxygen pairs (i.e. Mg2+―O2− and Al3+―O2− pairs on terrace) [44,45]. In the case of the Nb-MgAl, the Nb-doping in the MgAl mixed oxide structure likely created Nb5+―O2− pairs on the catalyst surface. Moreover, the Nb addition reduced the total basicity of the material (from 34.3 mV m-2 in MgAl to 18.8 mV m-2 in Nb-MgAl), preserving the base sites strength (Fig. 7-b). This can be explained by the formation of acidic Nb2O5 particles dispersed over the catalyst surface that is possibly causing the blockage of the surface base sites of the MgAl matrix. 3.2 Catalytic tests for glycerol conversion The Nb-based catalysts were evaluated for the conversion of the waste glycerol, as generated in the biodiesel industry. For most of the industrial processes, the continuous flow reaction systems save cost, energy, and operation time [46]. This motivated the investigation of the catalyst performances using a PBR reactor, as illustrated in Fig. 1. Firstly, the results revealed that the catalysts without calcination (i.e., the HT and Nb-HT) are not stable solids and caused the interruption of the reagent flow through the catalytic bed of the reactor. Thus, only the calcined catalysts (MgAl and Nb-MgAl) were evaluated and the results are shown in Fig. 8 . It is important to highlight that the catalysts exhibited high activity, showing high glycerol conversion (> 90 %). These values are remarkably high, taking into account that most of the studies involving glycerol oxidation are performed in batch operation using diluted solutions (< 5 wt%) [47,48]. The conversion values were almost constant during 6 h of operation, which is desirable for industrial applications [46]. Moreover, the deactivation of the catalysts was not observed, although some coke formation, which hinders the recovery of the spent catalysts, is clearly noted after the reaction. Three main reaction products (formic acid, diglycerol, and dioxane) were detected in the liquid phase. Moreover, several other products (e.g. 1-hydroxy-2-propanone, furfural, 3.3-diethoxy-1-propanol, acetic acid, butanoic acid, besides other unidentified products) were obtained in a negligible amount. Despite the similar conversion values for both catalysts, the product distributions were quite different (Fig. 8). The MgAl mixed oxide produced formic acid and diglycerol in a similar amount (about 35 %) and ≈ 10 % of dioxanes (Fig. 8-a). In the case of Nb-MgAl, a higher amount of diglycerol (≈ 65 %) was obtained, in addition to ≈ 20 % of formic acid and about 5% of dioxane (Fig. 8-b). The GC–MS chromatograms attest to the products formed (Fig. 8-c). This result indicates that the Nb addition to the catalyst affected the reaction products. This is possibly related to the acid/base properties of the catalysts. The glycerol oligomerization to produce diglycerol is reported in the literature to be catalyzed either by base or acid catalysts [49,50]. In this study, the higher acidity of the Nb-MgAl catalyst seems to increase the rate of glycerol dehydration to produce diglycerol [51]. Fig. 9 presents the reaction route for diglycerol production from glycerol using acid catalysts. Another valuable product obtained is formic acid. The formic acid production can be explained by the oxidative cleavage mechanism of the glycerol in the presence of the oxidizing agent (H2O2) [52,53]. In fact, blank experiments carried out without solid catalyst (i.e., waste glycerol and H2O2) also produced formic acid (≈ 30 %). Therefore, the results suggest that the oxidizing properties of the reaction medium associated with the acid/base properties of the solid catalysts create suitable conditions for the generation of formic acid and diglycerol from waste glycerol. Finally, the 1.3-Dioxan-5-ol was detected to a minor extent for both catalysts. The reaction between glycerol and formic acid can produce dioxanes [5]. Currently, several studies focus on the conversion of waste glycerol to high-value chemicals. Table 3 compares the activity of some catalysts reported in the literature, the different reaction conditions employed, and the selectivity towards diglycerol and formic acid. It is important to highlight that most of the studies use the high purity grade commercial glycerol in the catalytic tests, which considerably changes the catalyst activity and selectivity [5]. Furthermore, the continuous reactors (e.g. fixed-bed reactors) used in this work generate more useful data for industrial applications in large scale operations [46]. 4 Conclusion Heterogeneous catalysts based on Niobium-modified MgAl hydrotalcite were efficiently prepared by ion-exchange using peroxoniobate species as Nb precursor. A high amount of Nb (18 %) was incorporated in the Nb-MgAl catalyst. Structural characterizations indicate the formation of a composite material based on an MgAl mixed oxide matrix and Nb2O5, with an increased specific surface area. The catalytic tests for the conversion of waste glycerol demonstrate that MgAl and Nb-MgAl are very active and stable catalysts for use in a continuous-flow operation like PBR reactors. Three products with potential industrial applications namely formic acid, diglycerol, and dioxanes, were produced from the waste glycerol, as received from the biodiesel industry. Furthermore, the Nb addition modified the product distribution, producing mainly diglycerol of high interest to several industrial branches. Therefore, this paper presents novel potential catalysts for the obtention of chemicals of high industrial interest from renewable biomass (waste glycerin). This modern industrial use for glycerol can contribute to increasing the biodiesel sustainability. CRediT authorship contribution statement Izabela D. coredata.dc:description: Nb-modified MgAlmixed oxide catalysts were prepared by ion exchange using an MgAl hydrotalcite and peroxoniobate complex as precursors. After calcination, the Nb-MgAl revealed to be a composite material (MgAl mixed oxide with segregated Nb2O5 nanoparticles), with an increased specific surface area (229 m2 g−1) compared to bare MgAl (88 m2 g−1). XRD confirmed that part of the Nb atoms was inserted in the MgAl lattice thus causing the oxide doping. Furthermore, the Nb precursor favored the incorporation of a high amount of Nb in the catalyst (18 wt.%). Reactions performed in a continuous flow fixed-bed reactor (PBR) on a pilot scale showed that the MgAl and Nb-MgAl are quite active and stable catalysts for the conversion of the waste glycerol (> 90 %), as generated in the biodiesel industry. The valuable chemicals obtained (i.e., diglycerol, formic acid, and dioxane) demonstrates the potential industrial use of the catalysts presented in this work.
coredata.dc:title: Niobium-modified hydrotalcite catalysts: Sustainable conversion of waste glycerol to valuable chemicals
